div.p: AMERICAN TRADE IN EGYPT. VICE-CONSUL MORGAN’S REPORT. ( Continued from Saturday.) In compliance with the Department circular, I sent out a series of questions to those dealing in American goods, and interviewed many, and I give herewith a summary ot reports received and results of inquiries made verbally on the commercial relations between the United States and Egypt: (t) Are American manufacturers amenable to suggestions made from Egypt 1 The general experience is that they are not, and that they rather resent suggestions. This applies especially to the machinery trade.Uulike British manufacturers, the Americans refuse to guarantee their goods, contenting themselves by saying “the machines do the work we claim for them in this country (the United States),” and then proceed to put idiomatic expressions into their letters which are, in many cases, beyond the linguistic attainments of the in- tending agent or purchaser. One manufacturer lost a market for his "cultivators” owing to the springs carrying the body of the machine not being strong enough to properly support the machine when crossing the irrigation channels, with which all fields in Egypt are intersected. In reply to the suggestion made to strengthen the springs, he said that the machines were not made to “jump ditches.” 'These ditches are rillets of but 3 or 3 inches deep. Suggestions as to "finish” of certain wearing parts are as regularly scouted as they are made, as are also suggestions about modi- fications to make the machines more adaptable to the peculiar agricultural conditions of the country, the nature of the soil, etc. British manufacturers have long had the reputation ot acting in precisely a similar manner as that now attributed to Americans, but I have it from a gentleman returned from the United States, which he visited for the sole purpose of inducing manufacturers to introduce certain modifications in their agricultural machinery which were essential to their efficient working in Egypt, that he simply lost his time and money, and returning east he offered his sug- gestions to a British manufacturer, who at once took up the business. The purchaser is paying 30 per cent, more for his machines, but he gets what he requires,and also the guarantee for working efficiency, which the American manufacturers refuse. The coming market in Egypt is that for machinery, and it is needless to point out that all descriptions of machinery are referred to.

(2) Are orders sent direct to the manu- facturers or through European agents 1 It is seldom that any one repeats the ex- periment of sending a direct order to the ; United States. The invariable rule is "cash 1 with order,"and the general impression here is, that once he has the cash, the American manu- facturer troubles himself little as to when or ' in what condition the goods reach their destin- ation. Even where credit is given the bills ] mature long before the arrival of the goods and the purchaser has practically no remedy for loss owing to delays, broaching of cargo in ‘ transhipment, deterioration on voyage, and loss ' of a market demand, which, meanwhile, has ‘ been satisfied from elsewhere. Fifty-two days 1 would, as a rule, appear to be the quickest ( time in which a direct order from the United 1 States might be completed by the arrival of \ the goods here. In the case of perishable goods ' it would be safe to say that a second direct 1 order is never sent—as the buyer must risk 1 total loss—for it has happened that consign- ments of an alimentary nature have arrived ' from the United States in such condition that ' they have had to be destroyed by the health authorities, and although the instances may be ' few, their effect is very widespread. Id some instances orders sent direct to ' manufacturers in the United States are sent by 1 the manufacturers to agents in Europe for execution as a consequence of some arrange- ment for exclusive agencies being granted for particular zones. The system gives rise to dissatisfaction here, but the consequences to American trade are far more serious than would at first appear. It is with no little trepidation that I transmit for the information of American manufacturers the following, as, from my personal knowledge, I cannot vouch for what is related to me as fact, but it is for < those directly interested to make the necessary i inquiries into the subject and see about setting | their houses in order: “'The system of filling orders through Con- < tinental agencies is a gratuitous indication as i to where a new market is springing up, and no j sooner has an American article made its way | and created a demand than a cheap imitation i produced elsewhere is thrown on the market, the cards and packing being so gotten up that i the inexpert buyer sees no difference.” The person from whom I obtained this in- i formation made no complaint about the system. He really seemed to be amused at the idea that the Yankees, considering themselves to "cute,” should not have detected what was going on. It was a matter of indifference to him where the goods were produoed; he supplied a demand and made his profits in doing so, and it was not his afiair to suggest any change in the existing order of things.

MAGASINS VICTORIA. ECCLESTONE AND KEILL ENGLISH DRAPERY. NOTES FROM ASS10UT. ADVOCATE STRUCK OFF THE ROLL (From oob Correspondent). Assiout, May 13. The council of discipline for advocates gave judgment this week striking the name of Mikhail Eff. Hanna Sarabanah off the roll of advocates practising in the Native Tribunals. He was accused of having spent £2 (which had been given to him by one of his clients for Court fees) for his own purposes. He denied that be had received the money, but the fact was proved by his own handwriting. He has appealed against the judgment

A BRIDGE WANTED. In a few days we shall have the new build- ing for the Moudirieh ready. It is a very large edifioe situated on the Nile S.E, of Assiout Consequently, all Government offioes will be situated in El Hamra, on the Nile bank. El Hamra is a small village separated from Assiout by the railway lino. At present we have the Court, the TanzimOffice,theSurveyDepart- ment, the Irrigation Department, the Reservoir offices, and in a short time we shall have the Moudirieh, the GovernmentSchool, the Techni- cal School, etc., all situated in H amra. Therefore traffic between Assiout to Hamra will increase. As it is, a good many people have to cross the railway line, and very oiten the station gates are closed owing to trains passing. Frequently people have to wait half an hour for the opening of the gates, notwithstanding that they may have urgent business.

INFANT MORTALITY IN EGYPT. To ins Editor of the Egyptian Gazette. Sir,—The recent correspondence in your columns must have led many persons to believe that Egypt was the only country in which infants were sacrificed to maternal ignorance or negligence, and that if Egyptian mothers could be trained or coerced to bring up their off- spring in the enlightened methods prevalent in other countries a vast wastage of infant lives would be saved. As an Egyptian I had my doubts whether things were really much worse in this respect in Egypt than in other countries, but as our mentors were so positive in their statements, I hesitated to intervene in the discussion. From the “Graphic” of April 15th I, however, cull the following paragraph, which will I think show that there is room for missionary work among mothers even in Eng- land. Perhaps it would be advisable to print the paragraph in very small type, as I should be sorry to shook any susceptibilities :— "Would that the mothers of the lower classes could learn a little about the moral and physical natures of their unfortunate little ones ! With all the boasted spread of educa- tion, the mothers still feed their poor children on the most unsuitable food, still forget that milk,and milk only, is the natural nourishment for babies, and ic consequence, infant mortal- ity continues to increase in frightful propor- tions. At an inquest held last week it was proved that a woman had fed her baby on •boiley,' or ground biscuits, a food which the doctor declared could not be digested by any child under twelve months old. Think of the waste of life, the suffering, the expense entail- ed by this crass ignorance of the most common maternal duty, and let us not brag or pride ourselves on our system of education until the mothers of England have ceased to murder their children by slow and deliberate starva- tion.” Yours, etc., An Egyptian. Cairo, May 14.

div.div: PUMPS IN EGYPT. To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette. Sir,—Any discussion as to the relative merits of pumps is perfectly useless when based on mere assertions. The sole test is ooal consump- tion and water lifted. Unfortunately, reliable figures do not exist, and to obtain them quite a staff of trained men is needed to measure coal and water used by boilers, read gauges, and take discharges and lift for water pumped ; all of Which must be done simul- taneously and for a period of six hours on end. The Government returns for Mex pumping station give the general results for the year, but there are no figures which would be accepted by technical men as conclusively establishing the relative efficiency of Farcot and Gwynne. Till these figures can be pro- duced the pumps, in golfer’s phrase, are "Like as they lie” and their respective advocates may lie as they like.—I am, eto., An Apprentice. Alexandria, May 14.

div.p: SPORT AND PLAY. FOOTBALL. M. M. F. v. Inniskilling Corporals. For the fourth time this season the above teams met at Abbassieh in a friendly enoounter on Friday last. The match drew a large crowd of spectators. The police set the ball in motion. For a time the exchanges were very eveD, each side attacking in turn. Russell took a corner, the first of the match, but sent behind. A second followed, but like the previous one, it went behind. This half was greatly in favor of the boys, and they time after t:we pressed the police custodian, but all to no avail as Broadhurst was in good form. A neat centre by Russell looked well and Rafferty just missed the goal by inches. Oh the kick-off the police attacked and good play by Carter ended in Hopkins drawing first blood. Rafferty resumed operations and David- son had a run all to himself and centred well. Rafferty had a pot at goal, the custodian conceding a corner. In saving this was well taken, the goal being cleared for a moment, but R&fferty found the ball at his feet a few yards out and with an unsavable grounder made the scores equal Play after this became even. The police now took play in hand and the outside left getting a timely pass added number two. Excitement was at a great height just now. Rafieuy, getting on a single-handed run, ran through all opposition and passed to Davidson, who equalised the game onoe more. Aiken amused the spectators by some fancy work. Edgar was now playing a good game and checked the left wing time after time, play being somewhat exciting until Russell broke away, but Wingate returned in grand style. From this until half-time play was of a very even nature. Shortly after half- time was announced with the soore: Corporals Inniskillings Abbassieh oontingent 2 goals.

Military Mounted Police 2 goals. After the usual interval both teams re- sumed. The police at once assumed the aggressive. For sometime play was within goal's range but Carter shot wide. On the cick-off Ciee got possession and dodged a couple of opponents and gave to Russell, who sent a smart grasshopper in to the cus- todian, who fell on the ball, but Wingate managed to dear. Hopkins now showed to advantage and after dribbling the ball well up he gave to Field, who was ruled off- side. Tho representatives of Ireland now forced several corners, all to no purpose. The polioe attacked the right wing. They however wore scut back by Behan, who was in good form. The service oompauies now asserted themselves and Rafferty came through all by himself, but he shot against the custodian and immediatdy afterwards the ball hit the upright The police attacked in strong foroe but Murray was not called upon. The Ab- bassieh contingent pulled themselves together and forced two comers in quick succession, and although pressing strongly they were unable to penetrate the M. M. P.’s defense. Broadwood was asked after this to save from Davidson, which he did well Ireland now had a spell of attacking, Rafferty putting in several nice cross-shots, each of which the custodian saved in good style. The Inniskillings played the better football, but there was little to chose between them in points of attack. Cree and Russell were continually aggressive and forced another comer, which came to nothing. The Inniskillings still pressed and another comer fell to them, but to no purpose. The police now had an innings but did not stop loDg, as Behan and Supple were playing a cool and steady game and returned, lafferty who was playing a splendid game, got possession and led his forwards away. Cree raced up the field and gave to Russell, who with a rapid shot put his side ahead. Nothing further of any importance occurred up to full time, the score being: Corporals Inniskillings Abbassieh Contin- gent 2 goals. Military Mounted Polioe 2 goals. M. A. Lyons officiated as referroe.

ARMY AND NAYY. (From odb Correspondent). London, May 8. On the 14th of July next Colonel and Chief Paymaster T. 8. Coppinger, A. P. D., Distriot Paymaster in Egypt, will go on retired pay under the age rules. Colonel Coppinger, who is one of the few purchase officers now serving, joined the army nearly 40 years ago, and was transferred to the A. P. D. in 1876. Whilst paymaster of the 24th Regiment he saw servioe m the Zulu War of 1879 (medal with clasp). His impending retirement will be learned with regret by his many friends in the land of the Pharaohs.

Captain C. Pierce, Royal Berkshire Regi- ment, on promotion, has been re-appointed to the 1st Battalion at Dublin. Lieutenant Charles Howard, 1st Battalion RoyaUBerkahire Regiment, who was returned for trial to Dublin City Sessions for an alleged assatm on the polioe, failed to turn up at the Sessions last Saturday. His bail bonds were ordered to be estreated and a warrant was issued for his arrest It was stated in court that Mr. Howard, who had sent in his papers some time ago, had gone abroad, to Canada it Intelligence from Eequimalt, B.C., states that at the recent sale of Admiralty stores, consequent on the reduction of the Pacific Squadron, very low prices were realised. For instance, 102 torpedo nets, which ooet £40 each, were sold for £2 ; 1,500 ooaling baskets only realised £1 4s., 176 zino-lined oordite boxes went for £5, and other stores realised comparative trifles. The Admiralty set a reserve price on the large store of anchors and chains, to purchase which a Yankee ring came all the way from San Francisco.
